sect1.title: Managing Cluster Resources
sect1.para: In addition to configuring your cluster resources, &hawk2; allows you to manage existing resources from the Status screen. For a general overview of the screen refer to .

sect2.title: Editing Resources and Groups
sect2.para:
In case you need to edit existing resources, go to the Status screen and from the Operations column, select
action icon (arrow down) Edit .
The edit interface appears. For a primitive resource, the following operations are available:

listitem.para: copy the resource
rename the resource
delete the resource

sect2.para: If you edit a group, the following operations are available:

listitem.para: Create a new primitive as child in this group.
Rename the group name (ID).
Rearrange the group children by dragging the handle next to the name.
Rearrange the group children by dragging the handle next to the name

sect2.title: Starting Resources
sect2.para: Before you start a cluster resource, make sure it is set up correctly. For example, if you use an Apache server as a cluster resource, set up the Apache server first. Complete the Apache configuration before starting the respective resource in your cluster.

note.title: Do Not Touch Services Managed by the Cluster
note.para: When managing a resource via the &hasi;, the resource must not be started or stopped otherwise (outside of the cluster, for example manually or on boot or reboot). The &hasi; software is responsible for all service start or stop actions.
However, if you want to check if the service is configured properly, start it manually, but make sure that it is stopped again before the &hasi; takes over.

sect2.para: When creating a resource with &hawk2;, you can set its initial state with the target-role meta attribute. If you set its value to stopped, the resource does not start automatically after being created.

step.para: Log in to &hawk2;:
In the left navigation bar, select Status. The list of Resources also shows the Status.
Select the resource to start. In its Operations column click the Start icon. To continue, confirm the message that appears.
When the resource has started, &hawk2; changes the resource's Status to green and shows on which node it is running.

sect2.title: Cleaning Up Resources
sect2.para: A resource will be automatically restarted if it fails, but each failure increases the resource's failcount.
If a migration-threshold has been set for the resource, the node will no longer run the resource when the number of failures reaches the migration threshold.
A resource's failcount can either be reset automatically (by setting a failure-timeout option for the resource) or it can be reset manually as described below.

step.para: Log in to &hawk2;:
In the left navigation bar, select Status. The list of Resources also shows the Status.
Go to the resource to clean up. In the Operations column click the arrow down button and select Cleanup. To continue, confirm the message that appears.
This executes the command crm resource cleanup and cleans up the resource on all nodes.

sect2.title: Removing Cluster Resources
sect2.para: If you need to remove a resource from the cluster, follow the procedure below to avoid configuration errors:

step.para: Log in to &hawk2;:
Clean up the resource on all nodes as described in .
Stop the resource:
In the left navigation bar, select Status. The list of Resources also shows the Status.
In the Operations column click the Stop button next to the resource.
To continue, confirm the message that appears.
The Status column will reflect the change when the resource is stopped.
Delete the resource:
In the left navigation bar, select Edit.
In the list of Resources, go to the respective resource. From the Operations column click the Delete icon next to the resource.
To continue, confirm the message that appears.

sect2.title: Migrating Cluster Resources
sect2.para: As mentioned in , the cluster will fail over (migrate) resources automatically in case of software or hardware failures—according to certain parameters you can define (for example, migration threshold or resource stickiness). You can also manually migrate a resource to another node in the cluster. Or you decide to move the resource away from the current node and let the cluster decide where to put it.

step.para: Log in to &hawk2;:
In the left navigation bar, select Status. The list of Resources also shows the Status.
In the list of Resources, select the respective resource.

sect2.para: To allow a resource to move back again, proceed as follows:

step.para: Log in to &hawk2;:
In the left navigation bar, select Status. The list of Resources also shows the Status.
In the list of Resources, go to the respective resource.
In the Operations column click the arrow down button and select Unmigrate. To continue, confirm the message that appears.
&hawk2; uses the crm_resource -U command. The resource can move back to its original location or it may stay where it is (depending on resource stickiness).

sect2.para: For more information, see &paceex;, available from . Refer to section Resource Migration.

sect2.title: Monitoring a Cluster
sect2.para: After you have logged in, &hawk2; displays the Status screen by default. An icon in the upper right corner shows the cluster status at one glance. For further details, have a look at the following categories:

listitem.para: Only shown if errors have occurred.

Shows the configured resources including their Status, Name (ID), Location (node on which they are running), and resource agent Type. From the Operations column, you can start or stop a resource, trigger several actions, or view details. Actions that can be triggered include to set the resource to maintenance mode, migrate it to a different node, cleanup the resource, show any recent events, or edit the resource. toms 2016-08-17: Actually, the operations column is a little bit more difficult. If you put your resource into maintenance mode, the first entry (Maintenance) disappears.

Shows the nodes belonging to the cluster site you are logged in to, including the nodes' Status and Name. In the Maintenance and Standby columns, you can set or remove the maintenance or standby flag for a node. The Operations column allows you to view further details, for example, if a utilization, standby or maintenance attribute is set for the respective node.

sect2.title: Monitoring Multiple Clusters
sect2.para: The cluster information displayed in the Dashboard screen is stored on the server side and synchronized between the cluster nodes (if passwordless SSH access between the cluster nodes has been configured). For details, see . However, the machine you are running &hawk2; on does not even need to be part of any cluster for that purpose—it can be a separate, unrelated system.

procedure.title: Monitoring Multiple Clusters with &hawk2;
procedure.para: In addition to the general , the following prerequisites need to be fulfilled to monitor multiple clusters with &hawk2;:

listitem.para: All clusters to be monitored from &hawk2;'s Dashboard must be running &productname; &productnumber;.

If you did not replace the self-signed certificate for &hawk2; on every cluster node with your own certificate (or a certificate signed by an official Certificate Authority), log in to &hawk2; on every node in every cluster at least once. Verify the certificate (or add an exception in the browser to bypass the warning).

step.para: Log in to &hawk2;:
From the left navigation bar, select Dashboard.
To add dashboards for multiple clusters, click Add Cluster.
Enter a custom Cluster name with which to identify the cluster in the Dashboard.
Enter the Hostname of a node in the cluster.
To specify further options such as the update interval for &hawk2;, the port to connect to, or whether to use HTTPS (default), click Advanced and enter the details.
Confirm your changes with Add.
To add more clusters to the dashboard, click Add Cluster again and enter the details for the next cluster.
To remove a cluster from the dashboard, click the x icon next to the cluster's name.
To view details about a cluster, enter a password and click Connect.

&hawk2; shows you a summary with the status of the respective nodes, resources, and tickets.
Clicking a cluster name will take you to the Status view for that cluster, from where you can administer it as usual.

sect2.title: Using Batch Mode
sect2.para: The batch mode in &hawk2; can be used to do two things:

listitem.para: Stage all changes to the cluster and apply them as a single transaction, instead of having each change take effect immediately.
Simulate changes and cluster events.

sect2.para: For example, batch mode can be used when creating groups of resources that depend on each other, or to avoid intermediate incomplete configurations being applied to the cluster.
The batch mode has the following features:

listitem.para: While batch mode is enabled, the cluster simulator runs automatically after every change. The expected outcome of the change is reflected in the user interface.
When stopping a resource while in batch mode, the resource is not actually stopped. However, the user interface will update showing the resource as stopped, since the change is simulated.
The simulator will process all cluster configuration changes, including creating and removing resources, changing resource parameters or editing constraints.
It is also possible to simulate events in the cluster. This includes nodes going online or offline, resource operations and tickets being granted or revoked.

sect2.para: To work with the batch mode, do the following:

step.para: Click the Batch link at the top-level row. The batch mode bar appears below the top-level row.

Change your cluster. Note that wizards that perform actions beyond simple cluster configuration will process those actions on the live system, not simply as simulated changes. Take care when using wizards while in batch mode.

To review the changes you have made to the cluster, click the Show link. This will open a new dialog which shows a diff: lines starting with a - character represent the former state whereas a + means the future state.

To return to the regular mode, click Discard. A dialog opens where you can cancel the switch to the regular mode or proceed with Ok. This will discard any changes to the cluster configuration you have made.

Use Apply to make a single commit to your live configuration. A dialog opens where you can cancel the switch to the regular mode or to apply your changes to the live configuration. This will disable the batch mode.

sect3.title: Injecting Node and Resource Events
sect3.para: Inside the batch mode dialog you can call two event types: node events and resource events. When you click the Inject button, it gives you two choices:

listitem.para: lets you change the state of a node. Available states are online, offline, and unclean.
lets you change some properties of a resource. For example, you can set the operation, the node where it applies to, and the (simulated) result.

sect3.para: When you have created you node type, it will show up in the batch mode dialog. Proceed with Close.
